results.headline: Fright Night, With Thrills From Six Feet Under
results.summary_short: “I Sell the Dead” is a pastiche of old-fashioned horror flicks and an homage to the same.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Sell the Dead

results.headline: Homicidal Maniacs Also Like Hawaii
results.summary_short: “A Perfect Getaway” is just the thing for the summertime movie blahs: it’s a genuinely satisfying cheap thrill.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Perfect Getaway

results.headline: Out on the Highways in Search of Love, an Endlessly Elusive Quest
results.summary_short: An unconvincing mash-up of the real and the fake, “Paper Heart” wavers between identities to no clear purpose and to its considerable creative detriment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paper Heart

results.headline: The Latest in Elective Surgery Will Relieve You of That Nagging Soul
results.summary_short: “Cold Souls” is an ambitious, elegantly shot, tonally cool first feature written and directed by Sophie Barthes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cold Souls

results.headline: Guard Dog? How About a Psycho Ninja?
results.summary_short: In “The Collector,” one of the more doltish entrants in the torture subgenre, a robber stumbles upon a psychopathic second intruder.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Collector

results.headline: Earth in Peril, Children to the Rescue
results.summary_short: In “Aliens in the Attic,” basically a tweener cable movie on steroids, a group of green critters from space battle a group of youngstes as the fate of the planet hangs in the balance.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aliens in the Attic

results.headline: Seeking Dignity Amid Brutality
results.summary_short: Ulrich Seidl’s “Import Export” is an unflinching, at times almost unbearably hard yet moral look at human exploitation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Import/Export

results.headline: In an Industrial Belgian City, an Immigrant’s Brutal Dilemma
results.summary_short: “Lorna’s Silence,” with a narrative that turns partly on a mysterious pregnancy, evokes, subtly but unmistakably, a range of maternal biblical associations.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lorna's Silence

results.headline: From Flipper’s Trainer to Dolphin Defender
results.summary_short: The movie is a Trojan horse: an exceptionally well-made documentary that unfolds like a spy thriller.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Cove

results.headline: Man of the Cloth, With a Sudden Craving for Blood and Sex
results.summary_short: Park Chan-wook’s film is a bloodstained horror movie, a dark comedy, a noirish psychodrama, a melodrama, a literary adaptation and a vampire movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Thirst

results.headline: Armed and Dangerous in Australia
results.summary_short: This film is an affectionate, rollicking guide to the drive-in classics of Australian filmmaking from the 1970s and ’80s.
results.display_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation

results.headline: Rhythm in Retirement
results.summary_short: Dori Berinstein’s enjoyable documentary is about a 60-and-older hip-hop dance team.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gotta Dance

results.headline: Love in the Spirit World
results.summary_short: “Ghosted” is an elegant but unsatisfying drama of cross-cultural lesbian love triangles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghosted

results.headline: Stand Up and Deliver
results.summary_short: There’s something irritatingly self-satisfied about “Funny People,” which explains why, though it glances on the perils of fame, it mostly affirms its pleasures.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Funny People

results.headline: Several Points of View on a Single, Cruel Event
results.summary_short: The casting directors of “Fragments” deserve credit for assembling so much talent in one modest movie; if only Rowan Woods, the director, knew what to do with them.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fragments

results.headline: The Impure Morality of Nazi Resistance
results.summary_short: The director Ole Christian Madsen’s “Flame & Citron” is a fictionalized film, based on fact, about two Danish Resistance fighters.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flame & Citron

results.headline: Life: Perplexing, Painful, Precious
results.summary_short: Roy Andersson’s film is slow, rigorously morose and often painful in its blunt reckoning of disappointment and failure. It is also extremely funny.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You, the Living

results.headline: Desire and Disability: An Engineer’s Inner Battle
results.summary_short: Hugh Dancy plays a Manhattan engineer who suffers from Asperger’s syndrome in this charming romantic comedy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adam

results.headline: War of Words, Misspoken and Spun
results.summary_short: “In the Loop” is a sharply written, fast-talking, almost dementedly articulate satire on modern statecraft.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Loop

results.headline: Down and Out (and Disaffected) in St. Petersburg
results.summary_short: This astonishing debut, an experimental drama of wasted youth and low-rent Florida, is one of the best and boldest films of the year.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Loren Cass
